[[Anglo-Zulu War]] |awards= [[Victoria Cross]] |laterwork= }} '''John Berryman''' [[Victoria Cross|VC]] (18 July 1825 â€“ 27 June 1896) was a [[British Army]] officer and a recipient of the [[Victoria Cross]], the highest award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth]] forces. ==Victoria Cross action== Born in [[Dudley]], England, Berriman was 29 years old, and a [[Troop Sergeant-Major]] in the [[17th Lancers (Duke of Cambridge's Own)]] during the [[Crimean War]] when the following deed took place for which he was awarded the VC. On 25 October 1854 at [[balaklava|Balaclava]], [[Crimean Peninsula|Crimea]], (''see'' [[Charge of the Light Brigade]]) Troop Sergeant-Major Berryman, whose horse had been shot under him, stopped on the field with a wounded officer amidst a storm of shot and shell. Two sergeants ([[John Farrell (VC)|John Farrell]] and [[Joseph Malone (VC)|Joseph Malone]]) came to his assistance and between them they carried the wounded officer out of range of the guns.{{LondonGazette |issue=21971 |date=24 February 1857 |startpage=655 |endpage= |supp= |accessdate=29 March 2015}} [[Terry Brighton|Brighton, Terry]], ''Hell Riders: the Truth about the Charge of the Light Brigade''. London: Penguin, 2005 ISBN 0-14-101831-3. ==Further information== Berryman later achieved the rank of [[major]] and transferred to the [[5th Lancers]] in 1880.
